So who owns the elf record now?

Tuesday the Galt House Hotel in Louisville Kentucky invited everyone in the city to set a Guiness Book of World record for "gathering of most people dressed as elves".

So who owns the elf record now?

Kirby Adams, The Courier-Journal 3:38 p.m. EST December 9, 2014

The Galt House Hotel on Tuesday morning attempted to break the world record for “largest gathering of people dressed as elves,” drawing 639 participants. According to Guinness World Records, the current record was set last week by 1,763 “elves” at a Thailand mall.(Photo: Marty Pearl/Special to The Courier-Journal)

CONNECT 1 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Louisville gave it a shot but came up short in the elf department.

More than 600 people showed up at the Galt House Hotel's Grand Ballroom Tuesday morning dressed in red and green ready to break the official Guinness World Record for "largest gathering of people dressed as elves." The record, currently held by a shopping mall in Thailand, is 1,763, and the Galt House was ready for a crowd.

Employees set up 1,800 chairs in perfect rows. The same number of green or red plastic tunics and elf hats with ears were ready to be handed out to anyone in need of the official attire.

    "We cornered the market on felt," said Galt House general manager Terry Jenks, who complimented Dawn Hilton for personally sewing pointy ears to nearly 2,000 red or green felt caps. According to official Guinness World Record rules: "Elves" must be wearing both red and green clothing, plus pointy ears and an elf hat.

    While people of all ages were fine-tuning their elfwear and shuffling into place, toddler elves were hoisted on stage to dance for the crowd, and emcee Shannon Cogan of WAVE 3 (dressed as an elf, of course) encouraged older elves in the audience to join her to sing their favorite holiday songs.

    A few kids got to miss school to be a part of a world record attempt, and office groups showed up — such as a trio from the Kentucky Center who walked down to support their friends at the Galt House. One elf said, "A world record has always been on my bucket list and this didn't seem too difficult."

    The Guinness record rules state that all "elves" must remain seated for a minimum of 5 minutes while they are being counted. At 10:35 a.m. performers from the Christmas at the Galt House KaLightoscope Show — elf names: Joy, Neol, Buddy and Teddy — sang and danced on stage while Bill Carroll, CPA from Strothman and Co. (yes, he too dressed as an elf), began the official count.

    COURIER-JOURNAL

    Who is your favorite elf?

    A little side note: According to elf lore, the happy Lilliputians are no more than 4 feet tall, so, seated, all elves in the ballroom were the correct height whether they realized it or not.

    At 10:57 a.m., the announcement was made: The total number of elves with correct clothing in the Galt House Hotel's ballroom was 639, which was 1,125 short of the number needed to set the world record. "But, hey, we set the record for Louisville, for Kentucky, the Southwest and maybe even the United States — we'll have to check on that," said Amanda Lambert, with Galt House public relations. A pretty impressive feat, considering the idea was hatched only three weeks before.

    As for next year, with a bit more notice and a few more felt hats, Louisville is sure to set the "largest gathering of people dressed as elves" record, provided Santa gives the Galt House the OK.

    As participants left the Grand Ballroom, they were reminded to stow their elf hats and tunics in a safe place so they could bring them out next year.

    Like to get some information to me? Kadams@courier-journal.com and for more Buzz items Twitter @kirbylouisville.

    Trying to break a record at The Galt House
